--- title: "Real-World Impact of Antibacterial Resistance on Mortality in Marseille (Ongoing)" description: "Retrospective Multi-Hospital Real-World Evidence Study (2014–2018)" author: "Ousmane Diallo, MPH, PhD" date: "2025-11-11" highlight-style: pygments page-layout: article format: html: css: ../assets/css/remove-keyword.css --- ::: callout-warning ## Disclaimer – Educational Reimplementation Only This document presents a **methodological reimplementation** of a published study on the burden of antibacterial resistance on mortality in Marseille (AP-HM, 2014–2018). - No original **patient-level** or **confidential hospital data** are used here. - All analyses are based on **simulated** or **anonymized / reconstructed datasets** that replicate the patterns and methodology described in the original publication. - The aim is to demonstrate **Real-World Evidence (RWE) methods**, data engineering, and statistical modeling for my professional portfolio. The results presented here **must not** be interpreted as official AP-HM results. ::: # Overview This project reproduces, using simulated or reconstructed data, the analytical pipeline of a real-world evidence (RWE) study that quantified the impact of antibacterial resistance on in-hospital mortality among patients with blood cultures in the four University Hospitals of Marseille (AP-HM) between February 2014 and February 2018 ::: callout-note ## Real-world Evidence (RWE) Framing - **Study type**: Retrospective, multi-center, observational real-world evidence study - **Data source (conceptual)**: Routine blood culture results (MARSS surveillance system) linked with hospital mortality - **Population**: All patients with at least one blood culture performed in AP-HM during the study period - **Primary outcome**: In-hospital mortality - **Key exposures** - Resistance to key antibiotics for top bacterial species - Difficult-to-treat resistance (DTR) phenotype - Hospital-acquired infection, ICU admission, and other clinical factors ::: ## Research Question What is the real-world burden of antibacterial resistance on in-hospital mortality among patients with blood cultures in a large French university hospital system? ## Methods ### Study Design Retrospective observational study based on routine laboratory and hospital data.\ Patients with at least one blood culture were followed until hospital discharge or death. ### Setting Four University Hospitals of Marseille (AP-HM), France\ Study period: February 2014 – February 2018. ### Population All patients with ≥1 blood culture (positive or negative).\ Analyses focused on **positive cultures** involving the **10 most frequent bacterial species** in the deceased group, plus *Acinetobacter baumannii*. ### Variables - **Outcome:** In-hospital death (yes/no)\ - **Key exposures:** - Resistance to key antibiotics (e.g., ceftriaxone, ciprofloxacin, imipenem, amikacin)\ - **DTR phenotype**: resistant to all first-line agents (Kadri et al. definition) - **Covariates:** Age (\>60 vs ≤60), sex, hospital-acquired infection (\>48h after admission), ICU admission, length of stay (\>14 days), bacterial species. ### Statistical Approach - Descriptive analysis of bacterial spectrum and resistance rates.\ - Logistic regression to estimate odds ratios (ORs) for mortality associated with: - Hospital-acquired infection, - ICU admission, - DTR phenotype, - Specific bacterial species.\ - All results are based on **synthetic / simulated data** emulating published patterns. ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## Results (Illustrative) - Among all patients with blood cultures, those with **positive results** had nearly twice the mortality of those with negative cultures.\ - The most common bacteria in both groups were *Escherichia coli*, *Staphylococcus aureus*, *Klebsiella pneumoniae*, and *Pseudomonas aeruginosa*.\ - Resistance to **ceftriaxone**, **ciprofloxacin**, and **imipenem** was more prevalent among deceased patients.\ - **Hospital-acquired infection** (OR≈1.5), **ICU admission** (OR≈2.9), and **P. aeruginosa** or **E. faecium** infection (OR≈1.6–1.9) were independent mortality risk factors.\ - The **DTR phenotype** was rare (≈0.3%) but significantly more frequent among deceased patients. ![Fig.a Chord diagramm (deaths patients for top 20 co-infections isolated); b. Chord diagramm (survivors patients for top 20 co-infections isolated)](images/chord_diagram.png) ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="true" code-summary="Therapeutic alternatives on DTR isolates "} # ============================================================ # 1) DONNÉES (remplace les chiffres ci-dessous par les tiens) # Utilise les mêmes libellés d'antibiotiques que dans ta figure # Change "Serie A"/"Serie B" par les vraies étiquettes de légende. # ============================================================ enterobacteria <- tibble::tribble( ~antibiotic, ~`Serie A`, ~`Serie B`, "Gentamicine", 33, 0, "Amikacine", 33, 75, "Tigecycline", 100, 75, "Bactrim", 33, 0, "Colistine", 100, 100 ) abaumannii <- tibble::tribble( ~antibiotic, ~`Serie A`, ~`Serie B`, "Tobramycine", 67, 0, "Amikacine", 67, 50, "Bactrim", 33, 0, "Colistine", 100, 100, "Tigecycline", 100, 67, "Rifampicine", 0, 67 ) paeruginosa <- tibble::tribble( ~antibiotic, ~`Serie A`, ~`Serie B`, "Tobramycine", 67, 80, "Amikacine", 67, 85, "Colistine", 100, 100 ) # (Option) Personnalise les noms de série ici : legend_names <- c("Serie A" = "Blue series", "Serie B" = "Orange series") # ============================================================ # 2) FONCTION PANEL — construit un panneau barres groupées # ============================================================ panel_bar <- function(df, panel_title, tick_angle = 0) { long <- df |> tidyr::pivot_longer(-antibiotic, names_to = "series", values_to = "pct") |> dplyr::mutate(series = factor(series, levels = c("Serie A", "Serie B"), labels = legend_names[c("Serie A","Serie B")])) plot_ly(long, x = ~antibiotic, y = ~pct, color = ~series, colors = c("#4E79A7", "#F28E2B"), type = "bar") |> layout( title = list(text = panel_title, x = 0.5), barmode = "group", bargap = 0.2, xaxis = list(title = "", tickangle = tick_angle, categoryorder = "array", categoryarray = long$antibiotic), yaxis = list(title = "", range = c(0, 120), tickmode = "array", tickvals = seq(0, 120, by = 20)), showlegend = FALSE ) } # ============================================================ # 3) CRÉATION DES 3 PANNEAUX # (italiques via HTML pour les titres d'espèces) # ============================================================ fig1 <- panel_bar(enterobacteria, "Enterobacteria") fig2 <- panel_bar(abaumannii, "A. baumannii", tick_angle = 35) fig3 <- panel_bar(paeruginosa, "P. aeruginosa") # ============================================================ # 4) ASSEMBLAGE EN SUBPLOT + LÉGENDE COMMUNE # ============================================================ fig <- subplot(fig1, fig2, fig3, nrows = 3, margin = 0.06, shareX = FALSE, shareY = FALSE, titleX = FALSE, titleY = FALSE) |> layout( legend = list(orientation = "h", x = 0.5, xanchor = "center", y = -0.08), # Assure la même échelle Y sur chaque panneau yaxis = list(range = c(0,120)), yaxis2 = list(range = c(0,120)), yaxis3 = list(range = c(0,120)) ) fig ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## Discussion This real-world evidence analysis demonstrates that linking microbiology and hospital data enables quantification of the **clinical burden of antimicrobial resistance** in real practice.\ The approach can inform hospital policies, identify high-risk populations, and prioritize resource allocation for antimicrobial stewardship. ### RWE Value - Demonstrates secondary use of hospital RWD for public health.\ - Replicates real-world associations outside clinical trial settings.\ - Highlights integration potential with HEOR studies (e.g., cost of AMR-related deaths). ### Limitations - Retrospective observational design.\ - Possible misclassification of infection source.\ - Analyses conducted on **synthetic / anonymized data**, not actual hospital data. ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## Ethics and Data Governance This portfolio project complies with ethical standards for the use of health data: - No identifiable or proprietary hospital data were accessed.\ - All datasets were **synthetic, simulated, or anonymized**.\ - The work is for **educational and methodological purposes only**.\ - No institutional review board (IRB) approval was required for this reimplementation. This ethical framework aligns with international RWE guidance (FDA, EMA) promoting transparency, data privacy, and reproducibility. ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## Reproducibility and Skills Demonstrated **Analytical skills illustrated in this project:** - Real-world data curation and cleaning (R, tidyverse).\ - Epidemiological study design and variable definition.\ - Logistic regression modeling of clinical outcomes.\ - Data visualization (R/ggplot2) and RWE storytelling.\ - Ethical and regulatory awareness in secondary data use.
